93.title: Withdrawing participants from research and Subject Access Requests
93.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Withdrawing participants from research and Subject Access Requests


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

Participants can withdraw their consent at any time. They can also request to access personal information held about them by DfE, this is called making a Subject Access Request (SAR).
Under UK GDPR, individuals have the right to know what personal information is held about them and have it deleted in some circumstances.
Withdrawing participants from research
A participant could withdraw consent at any time so you’ll need to make sure they know how.
You’ll also need to make sure you remind them that taking part in research is voluntary:


during recruitment
at the beginning and end of sessions
whenever you think they feel uncomfortable

Deleting research data
You’ll need to delete any research data related to a participant who has withdrawn their consent.
Delete your research data for the individual if:


they withdraw consent during a session (stop the session if this happens)
they withdraw consent after the session 
you notice at any point that you do not have recorded consent for them

When you delete someone’s data, make sure you:


put any completed paper consent forms in a confidential waste bin
delete related recordings, files and database entries
delete their personal information, including contact details, from any files
tell them you’ve deleted their data

You’ll be able to deal with requests much quicker if you keep your personal data files organised. Read more about how to get informed consent.
Dealing with Subject Access Requests (SARs)
An individual usually has the right to know what information is held about them by DfE. SARs are usually made to find out what information is being held and why.
If you’re dealing with a SAR you must respond to the requester within one month. You can choose to use a response letter template to do this.
All SARs come through the ‘contact us’ service through Iris, DfE’s correspondence system. If you receive a SAR in a different way, email the Ministerial and Public Communications Division and ask them to log it.
Talk to the DPO or the UK GDPR policy team if you would like more specific advice about SARs.

94.title: Managing data when recruiting participants
94.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Managing data when recruiting participants


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

You can choose from a number of options for how to recruit participants from outside DfE (sometimes called external research).
You can choose to:


contact existing participants
use recruitment agencies
ask schools or charities you have an existing relationship with

You cannot use social media to recruit participants.
Make sure you choose the most appropriate method for your project.
Contacting participants from previous research
You can ask participants from previous research you’ve done if they’ve consented to being contacted about future research.
All the participant data you collect has a retention period, this is the length of time that you can keep someone’s data for. Do not contact existing participants if the retention period has ended.
You can also use existing contacts from lists you may have been given, for example from a union or a local authority.
When using existing contacts, make sure:


they have consented to being contacted
you tell them how you obtained their information 
you get informed consent for the new research if they want to take part 

Make sure you’ve got consent
When checking if someone has consented to being contacted again, make sure they’ve consented to the type of contact you want to make. Some participants may have only consented to being contacted by a specific team or under certain circumstances.
For example, a participant who has taken part in research about school teacher training may have consented to taking part in more research on that topic but would not be the right participant into commercial procurement. Contacting them incorrectly could make them feel overwhelmed or that their data is being handled incorrectly.
Using recruitment agencies
DfE has some agencies that can recruit participants for you. They can also deal with paying incentives to participants if your project is offering them.
Asking schools and charities
You may already have a relationship with an organisation like a charity or school. You can ask these organisations to advertise your planned research but make sure you consider the burden you might be placing on them, especially if they’re helping more than one DfE team.
When you contact the organisation, make sure you tell them:
- that you’re from DfE
- what you’re researching and the aim
- when the research will take place
- a contact who can deal with any questions they might have 
- a way to sign up (usually the researcher’s email)
You’ll also need to make sure you’ve described your approach in your recruitment plan.
If the retention period has passed
Do not contact a previous participant after the retention period has passed. It risks reputational damage if DfE are not handling data correctly.
If you notice that the data you received has not been handled correctly, inform whoever provided you with the data.
Make sure you read the guidance on checking how long to keep personal data for and familiarise yourself with how to anonymise data.
If you are unsure if data has been mishandled, please contact the Data Protection Office.

95.title: Introduction to following UK GDPR in user research
95.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Introduction to following UK GDPR in user research


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

Personal data is information that could identify a living individual. It is different from anonymised data, which cannot usually be used to identify an individual.
User researchers at DfE regularly handle personal data. Organisations like DfE have a legal responsibility to protect personal data when they collect, process, store and erase it.
As a user researcher you need to make sure that you understand how to protect personal data to comply with UK General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
Types of personal data
User researchers are often responsible for collecting personal data about users but everyone at DfE has a legal responsibility to protect the data collected.
Some types of personal data that user researchers often collect are:


special category data (includes information about disability, race and sexuality) 
addresses, occupations, dates of birth
unedited video or audio (raw data)
recruitment trackers which include names and contact details
IP addresses and any data from cookies

Identifying personal data
You need to make sure that you understand what personal data is so you can protect an individual’s information and follow the law.
Personal data is any information that could be used to identify a living individual. This includes information that could be used to indirectly identify someone when matched with other information about them.
In user research, personal data is referred to as:


personal identifiers (PID)
personally identifiable information (PII)
raw data 

User researchers should recognise that someone’s personal data also includes special category data, this is any information about race, ethnicity, sexual orientation or political views. Special category data needs a higher level of protection than ordinary personal data.
Principles to follow in user research
UK GDPR sets out responsibilities for organisations for collecting, processing, storing and erasing personal data. The aim of this law is to improve existing legal  protection over individual’s rights to their information in a data-driven, modern world.
UK GDPR follows 7 principles:


lawful, fairness and transparency 
purpose limitation (this means being clear about why you’re processing data) 
data minimisation (this means collecting the right amount) 
accuracy
storage limitation (this means not keeping data for any longer than you need it) 
integrity and confidentiality (security) 
accountability 

For user researchers, to follow the law and protect personal data you must:


make your reasons for collecting data clear to participants (this is informed consent) 
only collect data when there is a lawful reason 
not reuse data that you’ve collected in the past 
only collect data that you will need and use
make sure data is accurate and delete any inaccurate data 
only keep data for the length of time that you need it for and tell participants what this is 
keep it secure and only share it with people who need to know it

 Who is accountable for the data? (data controller)
If you’re processing personal or special category data in your role as an employee at DfE then DfE is accountable for the data and is the data controller.
What happens when you anonymise data
UK GDPR does not apply to fully anonymised data because after the process of anonymisation it can no longer be used to identify someone. It’s better to anonymise data as soon as you can.

96.title: Protecting personal data if your participants work in DfE
96.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Protecting personal data if your participants work in DfE


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

You still need to follow UK GDPR and protect the personal data of your participants if they work in DfE. This kind of user research is sometimes called ‘internal research’.
Types of internal research range from surveys about experiences like COVID-19 to research done to support an internal service or product like the DfE service manual.
Store their personal data
Personal data for internal research must be kept in the same secure and restricted folders where you keep external participant data.
Find out how to set up secure storage for files containing personal data.
Get consent to collect and use their data
You need to get consent from internal research participants to collect and use their personal data. You can use the consent form for external research to do this. A new form is being developed by the Research Operations team for getting consent for internal research.
Explain the purpose of your research to the participants, tell them what they’ll be asked about and what you’ll be doing with the data you collect.
You can ask them for feedback about their experiences working with your team. Make sure you explain this beforehand so they’re not pressured to give it when asked.
Anonymise the data
There are stricter rules for anonymising the personal data of internal participants than for external ones. It’s stricter because there is a risk that colleagues will be able to identify participants.
Make sure you only collect the data you need. When recording video and audio, voices may be recognisable to people who know the participant. Even if you blur out someone’s face, they may be identifiable from their clothing or accessories, for example, from something they wear every day like a wedding ring.

97.title: Setting up secure storage for personal data
97.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Setting up secure storage for personal data


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

User researchers store digital files in SharePoint and Google shared drives.
Your team might already have this set up. If not, you’ll need to choose a place to keep participant’s personal data and request access to set it up. You’ll also need to make sure you carefully manage who accesses the files.
Choose a platform to store personal data
As a user researcher at DfE, you’ll use Google Drive and SharePoint to store files depending on how your team is set up. The platform you choose should be decided by your team. They might already be using a certain platform, so check with them before requesting anything new.
The Data Protection Office and security team at DfE recommend using SharePoint to store personal data. You should keep in mind that if you have contractors on your team they may struggle to access SharePoint.
You can choose one platform for files that have personal data in them and another for files without personal data, for example, project files.
SharePoint folder for user researchers
A new process is being developed where you’ll be able to choose to keep participant personal data in the SharePoint workplace for user researchers. With SharePoint, all personal data is kept in one secure place – this mitigates risk by making it easier to manage.
Research Operations have worked closely with the Knowledge and Information Management Team (KIM) to make it easier for you to manage personal data in SharePoint, including moving, setting permissions and deleting.
Using SharePoint helps keeps participant personal data safe because:


you can only access this with an invitation link 
you’ll only be able to see the folders you’ve given access to 
nobody else will be able to access the data you store in SharePoint without permission 
you can use retention labels to make sure your data is automatically deleted at the end of a retention period - for example, - if you set a retention label of ‘2 years’ the file will be automatically deleted after 2 years 

Read about retention periods for keeping personal data.
Google shared drives
You may choose to keep personal data in Google Drive.
Unlike with Sharepoint, there’s no centrally managed folder (by DfE) for user researchers in Google Drive. You’ll need to create your own folders.
If you use Google Drive, Research Operations will not be able to see your folders or help you with managing access, so there is an increased risk to managing personal data. Do not add Research Operations colleagues to your folders because the way they are set up on the platform means there are too many for them to monitor.
The folder that you set up for personal data should be a Google shared drive.
Request access to shared drives
Fill out the new requests form or contact the digital tools team for more information. Anyone who needs access to the shared drive will need to have a digital.education.gov.uk account and it may take up to 48 to get access.
Do not contact individuals from the team directly, always use the #digital-tools-support Slack channel or email the team. This helps them manage their workload and get to your requests faster.
Manage who accesses the files
Only give others access to personal data that has not been anonymised on a ‘need to know’ basis.
Where possible, user researchers should be the only people accessing personal data. As a user researcher you should limit access to the data to the smallest number of people possible.
Give access to DfE information asset owners
DfE needs to keep up to date records of all the data it stores. Places where data is stored are called ‘information assets’. If they contain personal data, some examples of information assets are:


individual documents
folders containing multiple documents
a recruitment panel
an online service

All information assets should be recorded on the DfE information asset register.
Information asset owners (IAOs) are accountable for the security of data at DfE and they need to have access to folders containing personal data. IAOs are sometimes supported by information asset managers (IAMs). Some teams will have an IAM who is responsible for all of the personal data collected in user research.
Giving access to other people
Where it is not manageable for one researcher to conduct research and also manage all of the data compliantly, access can be given to someone who is not a user researcher, an IAO or an IAM, to help with data management. This person must understand UK GDPR and how it relates to good data management.
People outside of your team, an IAO or IAM can only be given access to personal data to help with compliance. You must give anybody else access for any other reason.

98.title: Getting informed consent
98.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Getting informed consent


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

You need to get informed consent from participants if you want to process their personal data. Informed consent means making sure participants have had the right information about your research before they consent to taking part.
To comply with UK GDPR, you must get informed consent from participants if you plan to process their personal data.
How to get informed consent from your participants
To get informed consent you’ll need to send the participant an information sheet and a consent form in an accessible format at least a few days before the research session date. If they do not return it before the session, you’ll still be able to complete it with them before you start.
You can use the information sheet template.
Getting informed consent means giving participants enough time to read the information sheet and think of any questions they might have.
You must tell them:


what they’ll be doing in the research
what data you’ll collect
what you’ll use it for 

Confirm consent before each session
Before you start your session, remind the participant about the information they’ve read on the information sheet and consent form.
You do not need to read them out verbatim. You might say:


are you still happy that we’ll share your anonymised data with the research team, and relevant teams in DfE? 
we will store your information for up to 2 years but may delete it before then
are you still comfortable if we record this session and with any observers present?

Make sure you tell the participant:


what they’re consenting to 
that taking part is optional 
that they can withdraw at any time 
how you’ll use the research data 

Get consent for sharing their anonymised data
It is ethical best practice to inform participants about where their anonymised data is being shared, even though UK GDPR does not apply to anonymised data.
They may also be comfortable with the research team seeing their faces and hearing their voice but might not want anyone else at DfE to, even if they’re anonymous.
To make sure we comply with ethical best practice we give participants the option to consent to sharing anonymised data.
Getting consent from children and vulnerable adults
For research with children and vulnerable adults you’ll need to get consent from the participant and from  their parent, guardian, carer or responsible adult.
Talk to your user research lead if you have any concerns about this.
Consent form templates
With support from content designers, we have created approved templates for you to use:


information sheets
consent forms
invitation letters

You can choose to use the example invitation letter or one of your own.
Get participant signatures
There are several different ways you can get participants to ‘sign’ their consent forms, you do not need to get a written signature to comply with UK GDPR. The Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) says you can get participants to tick a checkbox to signify consent and still meet the rules.
Face to face sessions
Face to face sessions are a good opportunity to talk to participants about the research and make sure they know what they’re consenting to, but you need to make sure you’ve sent them the invitation letter and information sheet before the session. If they confirm they’re comfortable taking part then they can complete the paper consent form in person. You’ll need to make an electronic copy, keep it securely and dispose of the paper form in a confidential waste bin.
Sessions done remotely
For sessions done remotely, you can send the participant their consent form by:


email
survey link
post

For any postal consent forms you receive back, make an electronic copy, store it securely and dispose of any paper in a confidential waste bin.
You can get verbal consent as long as the participant has read the consent form and information sheet.  You’ll need to read out each statement from the consent form and get the participant to reply with their consent to each of the statements.  You’ll need to record this on video or audio and store the clips alongside any related consent documents from the participant.
Storing consent forms
Keep consent forms in the user research folder for personal data. Find out how to set up secure storage.
If you use Microsoft Forms for your consent forms, the data submitted will be stored on the Microsoft website. You should download a copy of the responses once the research sessions have finished and save them in the user researcher folder for personal data. Delete the data held on Microsoft Forms.
This means all the personal data is kept in one place and makes sure we’re able to delete data if user researchers leave the team or DfE without doing so.
Consent forms:


must be placed under the same retention period as all material that comes from the research session itself 
should be the last document you delete when anonymising data or when the retention period is up 

Find out more information about deleting personal information.
Find out what to do if a participant withdraws their consent.

99.title: How long to keep information for (retention periods)
99.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

How long to keep information for (retention periods)


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

All personal data that you collect has a retention period, this is the amount of time you can keep it until you must delete it. If you anonymise personal data then it does not have a retention period.
You’ll need to check which retention period is appropriate for the data you’re collecting before you start your research. Only keep it for as long as you need it for or by the retention period end date.
Check which retention period you need to use
You can set your own retention period when you submit your research plan.
2 year retention period (recommended for all)
The DfE user research profession recommends that you choose a retention period of up to 2 years for all the personal data you collect on any project. Keeping personal data for 2 years or less means you’ll have enough time to analyse the data. It also mitigates against risks caused by unpredictable pauses in projects due changes in circumstances or funding, for example the impact of COVID-19.
3 year retention periods
You may choose a retention period of up to 3 years in exceptional circumstances on larger projects. Only choose 3 years if it’s likely that you’ll need to use the data you’ve collected after 2 years but before 3 years whilst on the same project. You must have a good reason for why you’re not able to anonymise the personal data you’ve collected.
5 year retention periods
You may choose a retention period of up to 5 years in some exceptional circumstances. Only choose 5 years if your project is classed as ‘longitudinal’, this means you’ll need to use this personal data over a 5 year period on the project. Longitudinal projects usually involve sharing with other government departments or doing statistical analysis where data cannot be anonymised in the usual 2 to 3 year period.
Manage retention periods on your files
You must make sure that data is deleted once the retention period ends. The best way to remember to do this is by using labels on your electronic files to remind you when the retention period is due to end.
SharePoint folders
You’ll soon be able to choose to manage the retention period on your files using labels in SharePoint, this option is currently being developed. User researchers often use labels to manage their files, if you use the retention period labels then the data will be automatically deleted when the retention period ends.
Google shared drives
You cannot use labels in the same way if you keep your files in a Google drive. If you’re keeping personal data in a Google shared drive then you should set reminders in your calendar to remind you to remove the data by the end of the retention period.
If you’re leaving DfE, make sure you tell your team about any reminders you’ve set.
The retention period end date is a legal deadline for deleting data. You should aim to delete any anonymised data before the end of the retention period. Find out how to anonymise data.

100.content:

Managing participant data correctly


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it



  !
  
    Warning
    Not managing personal data correctly is a serious offence
  

You must always manage the participant data you generate during your user research under UK GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation).
We have created user research guidance for managing data, with support from the Department’s Office of the Data Protection Officer. This guidance complements DfE’s GDPR guidance and policy that can be found on the intranet.
The UK GDPR guidance on these pages is specific for user researchers and explains how you can apply it to your day to day work.
GDPR is very important in DfE. In fact, we were audited by the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) in 2020. You can read the ICO report yourself and see a number of urgent and high risk priorities that DfE are tackling. If GDPR is not followed, we risk a fine from the ICO and risk reputational damage that could impact research.
Our guidance is not intended to make your work harder, but to protect users, yourself and the Department.
Further information


GDPR guidance and policy on the Department for Education intranet
You can learn more about UK GDPR on the Information Commissioner’s website.

101.title: Anonymising participant personal data
101.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Anonymising participant personal data


Beta This guidance is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback will help improve it

Anonymising personal data makes it easier for user researchers to use and share any data they’ve collected. Anonymising is removing the pieces of information that could be used to identify an individual.
If you anonymise your data then you can share it widely and store it without having to delete it later. Before you share, you’ll still need to check that participants have consented to having their anonymised data shared.
Anonymise notes as you make them
Most of the personal data can be anonymised whilst you’re collecting it. For file names and titles relating to the participant, you should use a unique identifier instead of their name.
Participants will often mention identifiable information during research, for example, the names of companies, colleagues, or the name of their child’s school. You can describe what they’ve said but you must remove any identifiable information.
Write your descriptions in square brackets to indicate that you’re not quoting verbatim. Some examples are:


Royal Mail would become ‘[a large postal carrier’]
Someone’s name would become ‘[a colleague’]
Broad Oak primary school would become ‘[their child’s primary school’]

Remove details from audio and video
If you’re sharing video footage with your team or a wider audience, you need to anonymise it.
Edit the videos and remove any spoken personally identifiable information.  This includes the names, places, places of work, addresses. Make sure you know what personal data is.
You do not need to blur video or distort people’s voices but you must make sure a participant has consented to having their anonymised video shared. If they have not consented, delete the recording once you’ve taken notes/transcribed.
You can use MS Stream to edit video files. Recordings can be edited by either bleeping out this info, or just cutting out the part where this information is said.
You need to keep unedited recordings in the restricted personal data folder until you’ve fully anonymised them.
You only need to anonymise what you plan to share. Most recorded video sessions are not shared with others. It’s easier and quicker to only anonymise what you want to share, rather than anonymising everything you record. Recordings that you will not share can be deleted.
You must also check who the participant has agreed for recordings to be shared with. For example, they may have consented to sharing with the research team but not the wider DfE.
Once recordings have been fully anonymised, you can store them without a retention period in a less restricted folder like your team’s general folder.
Pseudonymisation is different to anonymising
Pseudonymisation is a technique that replaces or removes information in a data set that identifies an individual. It means personal data can no longer be linked to an individual without additional information.
Read the ICO definition of pseudonymisation.


An example of pseudonymisation
It is best practice to anonymise data as soon as possible.
If you’re doing active research or you plan to contact a participant in the future, make sure you do not anonymise their data. In these cases pseudonymisation is a great security measure. But once you no longer need to contact the participants, you should anonymise or delete the data as soon as possible.
An example of using a unique identifier instead of a name could be using ‘P5R30502’ instead of the participant’s name, Joe Bloggs. Whilst you’ll know that ‘P5R30502’ took part in research, you would not know that P5R30502 is actually Joe Bloggs.
You’ll need to delete recruitment information to make sure the unique identifier cannot be linked to the participant name. For example, if you keep a recruitment tracker that says that Joe Bloggs took part in round 3 research on 5 February then you would be able to link the participant to the unique identifier.
In fact, even if you only know Joe Bloggs took part in round 3, there’s still a chance he’s identifiable. Pseudonymisation is effectively only a security measure. It does not change the status of the data as personal data.

Delete consent forms after you’ve anonymised data
Due to the importance of consent forms it may seem scary to delete them.
If all your data is fully anonymised but you’re still storing consent forms, you’re still processing personal data.
Once you’ve fully anonymised (not pseudonymised) your participant personal data from your research, you should delete your consent forms.  DfE is developing training on how to delete consent forms, you should check with your user research lead that data is fully anonymised before deleting consent forms.
You may be concerned that a participant might want to withdraw their data or make a Subject Access Request (SAR) after you’ve anonymised it. There is no longer any data to delete or to send them as there is no way for you to identify it. This is normal practice and compliant with data protection. This is explained to the participant in our information sheet template which they read before research.
Consent forms should be the last piece of personal data you delete. If you cannot anonymise because you’re still contacting them, they must be deleted before the retention period ends regardless of whether you still need them.
Speak to your team before you share findings
Depending on what a participant has consented to, you can share anonymised findings with whomever you wish.
Leadership within DfE have decided that user researchers should always inform participants on how their data is being handled (and who it’s being shared with), including anonymised data.
Remember to always check that your team is happy to share the findings.
Contact Research Operations if you’re unsure what your consent form says.
It’s everybody’s responsibility to make sure the way they handle participant data is compliant with data protection laws.
Talk to your team and your user research lead if you have any concerns. Contact the Data Protection Office (DPO) if you have any concerns about UK GDPR.

Training and online resources


Beta This content has been written by our user research community, and is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback and ideas will help develop it

Training budgets sit in your portfolio or business area. If you have identified a training course you’d like to take (using the user researcher capability framework to identify your development needs, and with the support of your line manager, profession manager, or mentor) then speak to your line manager about how funding works.
Introduction to user research in government
The cross-government Understanding users and their needs training course is a good introduction to conducting user research in the context of government.
Online resources
Our user research community has crowd-sourced some books and websites that we’ve found interesting and useful:
Books:


Interviewing Users: How to Uncover Compelling Insights by Steve Portigal


Steve also ran a podcast on user research you might find interesting, called Dollars to Donuts

Just Enough Research by Erika Hall
Good Services by Lou Downe
User Research: A Practical Guide to Designing Better Products and Services by Stephanie Marsh
Think like a UX researcher - user experience strategy by David Travis and Philip Hodgson

Websites:


UXmatters


a great source of articles about user research and the pros and cons of various methods
For example: Unmoderated, Remote Usability Testing: Good or Evil?

Neilson Norman group - lots of articles, all really useful


When to use which user-experience research methods
Empathy mapping
Thematic analysis
Writing usability tasks
UX research cheat sheet


What next?
In the future, we plan to develop a cross-profession training strategy, with a mix of in-house training courses and recommended third-party training. See our profession roadmap.
You can join the Training working group and help them do this.

108.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Specialist software and hardware


  !
  
    Warning
    You must not install any software or use any web service that collects personal data, unless it has gained DfE data protection and security assurance
  

There are a range of tools you will need when conducting user research. Some of these are available to you via centrally managed licenses, while others can be purchased by your team.
Laptops and access to DfE systems
If you are a civil servant DfE user researcher, our standard laptops aren’t always powerful enough for tasks like video editing, or some specialist software. Instead, you can order a more powerful laptop. Go to the Service Portal and search for ‘Power device’.
There are certain DfE internal tools and services (including some that you might need for desk research, like the Department’s Research and Evidence Directory, and some data dashboards) that can only be accessed by civil servants, or by contractors with a DfE laptop. If you are a contractor who needs to access these services, then you can ask a civil servant in your team, or you can ask your delivery manager to arrange for you to be loaned a DfE laptop.
Specialist software and online tools
There are some specialist user research software and online tools that are available to all user researchers. The current list is on the Digital Tools Support team website. You can contact that team for more support in the Digital Tools Support Slack channel
There may be a cost to your team for these tools, so speak to your delivery manager first.
You can also speak to the Digital Tools Support team about buying licenses for other software or online services. They can tell you what you and your delivery manager will need (e.g. a business case and budget approval). If the software or service doesn’t already have data and security assurance, they will arrange this. This process can sometimes take a few weeks, so leave plenty of time to do this.
You can also contact them if a tool you need to use is not available, or if you already have access to digital tools and have questions.
Other tools
We don’t currently have any centrally available tools like video cameras, dictaphones, etc. We’re working on this (see our profession roadmap).
For now, if you need these, you can buy them with your team or programme area’s budget. Your delivery manager can help you with this.

114.title: Style guide and patterns
114.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}

  gtag('config', 'G-');

Style guide and patterns
Content style guide


We speak to the reader (“you should” not “user researchers should”)
We don’t repeat what DfE is saying elsewhere (e.g. link to a relevant page on the intranet, rather than repeating or paraphrasing it)
We don’t simply repeat or paraphrase GOV.UK content, we link to it - unless we’re adding extra context or information (while linking to the original GOV.UK content)
If content is still in development or in beta, we clearly state this
We open all links in the same browser tab (i.e. don’t use target=“_blank”) except for opening Slack channels and otherwise taking users out of the browser.
‘participants’ or ‘research participants’, not ‘users’
We follow the GDS content style guide

Patterns
Beta content
If the content isn’t finished or is likely to change, we state that it’s in beta and add this block to the top of the page (directly under the H1). The wording can change slightly as needed, but make sure there it includes the link to the feedback page.


Beta This guidance has been written by our user research community, and is in beta. It is likely to change over time.
Your feedback and ideas will help develop it

Critical content
If the page contains something critical that a UR must or must not do, we show a warning at the top of the page. This should come below the H1 (and below the Beta message is this is present). ‘Critical’ means that the department could get in legal trouble, the user researcher could be breaking the terms of their employment, a team could fail assesssment, or some other serious consequence.


  !
  
    Warning
    If you don’t research inclusively then you are not meeting the service standard. You may also be breaking equality law
  

Must/Must Not/Can lists
Sometimes we need to clearly tell URs what they can do, must do, and must not do in certain situations. Keep the list simple, as below, and make sure you clearly tag what the list is.
Can - during a pre-election period you can:
During a pre-election period, you can:


recruit members of the public through recruitment agencies, as long as initial adverts and screeners do not mention or imply that the research is for a government service
invite participants from existing user research panels - this is especially helpful for any sensitive research 
use internal channels to recruit colleagues for user research on internal aspects of services.

    User research in Department for Education

       
         This manual is currently in development, and will launch into Beta in mid-December. Until then, you should not use or rely on any of the content it contains.
      

      Guidance, information and support for any user researcher working in Department for Education
      This manual should be used alongside the DfE Apply the Service Standard manual, and it complements the user research section in the UK Government Service Manual, which covers user research more broadly.
      
       
         
            
               New to Department for Education?
               What you need to know if you’ve just joined DfE as a civil servant or contractor user researcher.
            
         
         
            
               Community meetups and Slack channels
               How we come together as one DfE user research community to learn and support each other.
            
         
      
      
    
  



   
      Our working principles of user research Beta
      These are the principles that, as a user researcher at DfE, you should always follow. Find out more about our principles, why they exist, and how we help you meet them.
      
         
            
               
                  1. We include all of our users, and bring them to the heart of the department’s work
                  This principle is about researching in a way that is inclusive of all our users, and ensuring our teams understand them and their needs.
               
            
            
               
                  2. We are objective and use evidence
                  This principle is about helping our teams to do what’s right for users, avoiding assumptions, and mitigating biases.
               
            
            
               
                  3. We do high quality, safe and ethical research
                  This principle is about ensuring we and our teams always meet high professional standards for user research.
               
            
            
               
                  4. We are adaptable and collaborative, and focus our research in the right places
                  This principle is about the way we work in our teams and with other user researchers to help deliver DfE’s goals.
               
            
            
               
                  5. We learn as a commnunity and by ourselves
                  This principle is about developing as user researchers, and coming together in our user research community.
               
            
            
               
                  6. We celebrate our work, and help others understand what we do
                  This principle is about advocating for user research in our teams, the department, and the wider world.
